system.description:
When the players take action the Referee works down this list:

  1. Intent: What are you trying to do?

  2. Leverage: What makes it possible?

  3. Cost: Would it use a resource, cause Virtue Loss, or have a side-effect?

  4. Risk: What's at risk? No risk, no roll. Otherwise make a Save or a Luck Roll.

  5. Impact: Show the consequences, honour the established risk, and move forward.

SUCCESS

When the players succeed at a significant action the Referee does one of the following:

  • Advance: Move in a good direction.

  • Disrupt: Lessen a threat.

  • Resolve: Put a problem to rest.

FAILURE

When the players fail at a risky action they might still complete the action, but always suffer negative consequences:

  • Threaten: Create a new problem.

  • Escalate: Make a problem worse.

  • Execute: Deliver on a threat.

IMPACT

Whether a success or a failure, ensure that the players’ actions have an observable impact on the world. The best types of impact have both immediate and lasting consequences, always moving things forward.

At the end of each session, or during a natural break in their journey, the group decides how much time will reasonably pass:

  • None: Pick up where you left off.

  • Weeks: Continue on to the next significant seasonal event.

  • Months: Move to the next Season.

  • Years: Begin a new Age in Spring.

If uncertain, roll:

[[/r 1d6]]

PASSAGE OF TIME

1

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season} or @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.9btBt0rE5AvXw3mt]{Age} turns now.

2-3

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season} or @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.9btBt0rE5AvXw3mt]{Age} turns after next session.

4-6

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season} or @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.9btBt0rE5AvXw3mt]{Age} continues.

BETWEEN SEASONS

Restore @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.a3wuqgFMQEMjrm0S]{Virtues}and choose one:

  • Pilgrimage: Learn about an unknown part of the Realm.

  • Courtesy: Establish a new contact or earn a favour.

  • Service: Make a small improvement to the Realm.

BETWEEN AGES

Restore @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.a3wuqgFMQEMjrm0S]{Virtues}, gain 1 @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.p1BbrqwB3IL5KnsP]{Glory}, choose one:

  • Duty: Make a significant improvement to the Realm.

  • Succession: Establish a successor and/or have them Knighted.

  • Legacy: Your successor gains half of your current Glory.

Each Life has 3 Ages:

  • Young: Green, always learning.

  • Mature: Seasoned, in their golden years.

  • Old: Grey, considering their legacy.

When a character becomes Mature they reroll each Virtue on [[/r d12+d6]] and keep the result if higher.

When a character becomes Old they reroll each Virtue on [[/r d12+d6]] and keep the result if lower. Old characters lose [[/r d12]] VIG at the end of each Age. If this takes them to VIG 0 they die peacefully.

Take the Attack dice noted on your weapon(s), shield, and granted by bonuses.

Go through the following steps in order:

  1. All combatants attacking the same target roll their dice at the same time.

  2. If the target or their nearby allies can @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.G4QYjtCVWeZP6YIA]{Deny}they may use it.

  3. Attackers may perform @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.U8Vl83tcDkRYLmpZ]{Gambits}.

  4. Take the highest die remaining.

  5. Add any extra Damage from attackers who are @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.U8Vl83tcDkRYLmpZ]{Bolstering} the Attack.

  6. Subtract the target’s total Armour score.

  7. The Attack causes that much Damage.

So a Knight with a mace (d8) and shield (d4) is aided by an ally with 2 daggers (d6 each). They roll d8 and d4, and 2d6 respectively. The dice show 7, 3, 1, and 5. The highest die is 7. The 5 is spent on a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.U8Vl83tcDkRYLmpZ]{Gambit} to Bolster the Damage to 8. The target has Armour 2 (helm and shield), reducing the Damage to 6.

Impaired attacks roll d4 only and cannot gain bonus dice or benefit from Feats.

Blast attacks target everybody in their area, rolling each separately.

Travel through a Barrier is not normally possible, though locals might know a way. Attempting to travel through a Barrier wastes that Phase of the day, but still causes a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.PxSDkx5wU6kRX5V3]{Wilderness Roll}.

Restore @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.a3wuqgFMQEMjrm0S]{Virtues}, gain 1 @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.p1BbrqwB3IL5KnsP]{Glory}, choose one:

  • Duty: Make a significant improvement to the Realm.

  • Succession: Establish a successor and/or have them Knighted.

  • Legacy: Your successor gains half of your current Glory.

Restore Virtues and choose one:

  • Pilgrimage: Learn about an unknown part of the Realm.

  • Courtesy: Establish a new contact or earn a favour.

  • Service: Make a small improvement to the Realm.
Blast attacks target everybody in their area, rolling each separately.
These are gained from useful information, shrewd preparations, or a tactical advantage. +[[/r d8]] is a typical bonus.

When sleeping outdoors make a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.PxSDkx5wU6kRX5V3]{Wilderness Roll} as normal, ignoring Landmarks. Hostile Omens prevent proper sleep, while others may not occur at all if they are improbable as nighttime activity.

A @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ml5gCjU1JAnzXajw]{Seat of Power} carries similar problems to a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.dJeZTvmudZnjrS96]{Holding}, elevated to a larger scale. Threats arise from within your @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.X1lghTTFxdKGH1z4]{Court}, within your @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.3hsMdqsglAWNjUQu]{Realm}, and from @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ehLtyf20u7JwlsrK]{beyond your borders}.

Knights live between two worlds. One of rank, oath, and rule of the worthy. The other of chaos, brutality, and rule of the strong.

Often, having the audacity to seat yourself in a Holding is enough to make you the ruler.

Holdings and Realms seized by force and left unchallenged tend to have a period of turmoil before adapting to the new status quo.

Courtiers breed problems, especially when they hold leverage over their ruler, whether family influence, dark secrets, or military might. Here a ruler must tread carefully, as obvious solutions always leave at least one party feeling mistreated.

Every Season brings some drama. Spark Tables can help to describe this.
Roll to see how you’re involved:

[[/r d6]]

DRAMA IN COURT

1

You are personally involved.

2-3

You are involved by association.

4-6

You are not involved.

BREAKING THE RULES

The guidelines on this page make for a typical Realm, but they can be bent or broken in creating your own Realms.

THE HEX MAP

A Realm is mapped on a hexagonal grid covering the loose rule of a Seat of Power. A 12x12 grid is typical, whether the Realm is landlocked, coastal, or an island chain.

Typically, players get a copy of the map with Holdings and general terrain marked. They cannot see Myths, Landmarks, and Barriers.

The distance covered by each hexagon is a Hecksleague, commonly called a Hex.

This distance represents a few loose factors:

  1. The area a hill fort can overlook
  2. The area that guards can patrol in a day
  3. A return hike to a neighbouring Hex gets you home before dark

WILDERNESS

Most Hexes are Wilderness, with a variety of terrain types. Spark Tables can help with this. As a general guide create clusters of [[/r d12]] hexes of the same terrain type.

Some Hexes have a Barrier on one or more of their edges, typically a sudden altitude change or impassible feature. These cannot normally be travelled through. For a typical Realm, place a number of Barriers equal to one sixth of your total Hexes.

Most Realms have a navigable river passing through and a few large lakes spanning whole or multiple Hexes.

HOLDINGS

Place 4 Holdings a good distance apart, typically castles, walled towns, fortresses, or towers, held by Knights or influential Vassals. Most of the Realm lives within their walls or the surrounding Hex.

Designate one Holding as the Seat of Power. This is the Holding of the ruler of the whole Realm, commonly a Knight.

MYTH HEXES

Place 6 Myths in remote places. Number them as 1-6. The Hexes are clearly affected by the presence of their Myth.

LANDMARKS

Some Wilderness Hexes contain a Landmark. These are discovered when travellers roll 4-6 on the Wilderness roll. A typical Realm has 3 or 4 of each type of Landmark. Mark them with their initial or an icon.

Even characters who know a Landmark’s location must still make a Wilderness Roll to check for Omens as they travel there.

Each Landmark type covers a range of specific features, with prompts provided on Knight and Myth pages later in the book.

The course of the game may create new Landmarks or remove or alter existing ones.

The 6 types of landmarks are:

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.gEhHqMT5ciuQNZXm]{Dwellings}
  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.QWZ5Xsa3vuo5Bf69]{Sanctums}
  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.lBdvsLmaxCzXExnv]{Monuments}
  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.UuZ3UFDChYMN7gTh]{Hazards}
  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ihrxnfnNnK4x8KPd]{Curses}
  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.TuBkbx1jAFCmrp19]{Ruins}

ADDING DETAILS

Spark Tables can add detail to significant locations and people in the Realm.

DISTANT REALMS

Realms are usually bordered by water, mountains, or wasteland, though claims are often disputed. Travelling to a distant Realm normally sees you arrive in the next Season.

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Ht6YdS1x8Va8s16q]{Ruling a Domain} is an exercise in ongoing disaster management.

At the start of a Season or when returning from a long absence, roll:

[[/r d6]]

CRISIS ROLL

1

Calamity: Immediately gain 2 Crises.

2-3

Dilemma: Choose between 2 Crises.

4-6

Prosperity: Times are good.

Crises apply to the whole Domain, not a single character, and remain until resolved.

They can be chosen by the Referee, or rolled:

  1. Chaos - Lawlessness in the land Resolution: Enforce a sense of justice.

  2. Debt - Dire need of coffer and coin Resolution: Restock the treasury.

  3. Famine - Empty plates, empty fields Resolution: Get food into the stores.

  4. Misery - Vassals question why they toil Resolution: Raise the spirits of the people.

  5. Panic - The weak tremble with unease Resolution: Ensure the Vassals feel safe.

  6. Doubt - Seeds of betrayal against you Resolution: Assert your authority to rule.

If a season ends with 3 or more unresolved Crises then the Domain goes into @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.T74kT3xY6yPC3MK2]{Misrule}.
Blights on the land that throw you off course. If you travel in the next Phase it counts as @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.730Af1FmIdloG4vY]{Travelling Blind}.

The attack’s Damage is deducted from the target’s GD.

If they have at least 1GD remaining then they Evade the Attack.

If it leaves them with exactly 0GD then they gain a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.sc76aTlM7OLBPigZ]{Scar}.

If it exceeds the target’s GD, the excess is deducted from VIG and they are Wounded.

If they lose half or more of their remaining VIG it is a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Kkozior5c3JbSn39]{Mortal Wound}. Mortally Wounded targets are down and dying. They die if left untended for an hour, but can be patched up

in a few moments.

If Damage reduces the target’s VIG to 0, they are @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.277DeX9r1AioelSw]{Slain}.

Even the boldest Knight can die a sudden or ignoble death. Prepare yourself for this.

When a Knight dies the player creates a new Knight and they are added to the Company as quickly as possible. Alternatively they may assume control of a Squire or follower.

Rebuff an attack before it lands

  • Use after an Attack roll against you or an ally within arm’s reach.

  • Discard one Attack die from the roll.

  • Pass a SPI Save or become Fatigued.

When travelling in lands at the mercy of dire weather, roll at the start of each Phase.

[[/r 1d6]]

DIRE WEATHER

1

Dire weather. You can’t leave the Hex and can’t get proper sleep.

2-3

Looming threat. If this is rolled a second consecutive time, treat as dire weather.

4-6

Fine weather for travel.

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.3hsMdqsglAWNjUQu]{Realms} are usually bordered by water, mountains, or wasteland, though claims are often disputed. Travelling to a distant Realm normally sees you arrive in the next Season.

Two combatants can mutually agree to engage in a duel, or joust if mounted.

They fight as normal but their attacks are rolled and resolved simultaneously, including the effects of Gambits. Both combatants can use Feats before the attacks are resolved.
Sets of humble homes amidst the wilds.

At the end of each session:

  • Discuss if it would feel right for a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season} or @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.9btBt0rE5AvXw3mt]{Age} to pass between now and the next session.

  • If a Season or Age passes, then follow the procedure detailed.

  • Ask the players if they have any plans or ambitions for the next session. This gives you a direction for any preparation you do before then.

When ruling exploration actions, follow the standard @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.U0cRZvrvdyQCKHy8]{Action Procedure}. In particular, consider whether the action will take a whole Phase of the day to carry out.

As with other Actions, the players should know the risks before they commit to it.

If the Action calls for a Save the Company decides who rolls, using their Virtue.

Even if they fail the Save, the goal might still be achievable, but now faces an obstacle, a hostile encounter, or an additional cost.

While the cause and consequence of failure can be personal, they also represent the whims of nature, bad weather, shifting land.

If it is unclear which Virtue to use, consider the main activity involved in the risky part:

  • Vigour: Strength or physical stamina.

  • Clarity: Senses or mental quickness.

  • Spirit: Social or emotional influence.

Characters who are caught with their guard down or otherwise defenceless are Exposed and act as if they have 0GD. If they remedy their situation then they are no longer Exposed. Traps and ambushes typically catch victims Exposed.

• Some believe there is truth in the sky: the stars, moon, sun, positions, and motions.

  • Some look to nature: the turn of seasons, the sound of trees, the wisdom of beasts.

  • Some believe the sacred stories that weave into Myths, guiding us to the City.
A Fatigued character is unable to use @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Ii4ZqGwzc3qZWA8B]{Feats} until they rest.

These special actions known by Knights can be performed as described. Using Feats risks the Knight becoming Fatigued which prevents them from using further Feats until they rest.

After using a Feat the user must pass a Save or become Fatigued, unable to perform Feats until they rest. Each Feat can only be used once per Attack by each combatant involved.

SMITE - Release your righteous fury

  • Use before rolling a melee Attack.

  • The Attack gains either +[[/r d12]]or @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Q84GshhKtznJytyY]{Blast}.

  • Pass a VIG Save or become Fatigued.

FOCUS - Create an opening to exploit

  • Use after rolling an Attack.

  • Perform a Gambit without using a die.

  • Pass a CLA Save or become Fatigued.

DENY - Rebuff an attack before it lands

  • Use after an Attack roll against you or an ally within arm’s reach.

  • Discard one Attack die from the roll.

  • Pass a SPI Save or become Fatigued.

Create an opening to exploit

  • Use after rolling an Attack.

  • Perform a Gambit without using a die.

  • Pass a CLA Save or become Fatigued

Attackers may discard any number of Attack dice of 4 or higher to perform Gambits, each causing one of the effects below. The affected foe must be a target of the original attack.

For Gambits other than Bolster and Move the target receives a VIG Save to ignore the effect.

  • Bolster the Attack for +1 total Damage

  • Move after the Attack, even if you already moved or are unable to move

  • Repel a foe away from you

  • Stop a foe from moving next turn

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.w0AdMBWGQLWhQHd8]{Impair} a weapon on their next turn

  • Trap a shield until your next turn

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.arw6LSD4H5hvFDS3]{Dismount} a foe

  • Other effect of a similar level of impact

If a die of 8 or higher is used in melee then a Strong Gambit is performed and the attacker chooses one of the following:

  • No Save is granted to the target

  • Greater effect such as disarming an item, breaking a wooden shield or weapon, or removing a helm. This does not increase the Damage from Bolster.

Everybody knows something about @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.zR5oyR4ZccCyWZg2]{Myths}. How much depends on who they are.

Vassals know about their nearest Myth, and its general direction. If it is adjacent to their home then they know its precise location.

They know Landmarks in their home and neighbouring Hexes.

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.GaN0dPf1jqeQ8utO]{Knights} and Vagabonds have roamed enough to know about a random Myth of the Realm and its rough direction. They also know of the nearest @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Fy9hueqdKhEX0zYj]{Landmarks}.

All of the above know rumours that warn of dangers, but not how to avoid or undo them.

@UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.XD4dA6vKjurF4VsY]{Seers} know the rules of all Myths, their secrets, and their locations. They know their weaknesses, and cures to their maladies. They know all Landmarks in the Realm. Such vast knowledge isn’t given freely.

One player is the Referee. They should read through to the end of the rules section.

The other players can go straight to the @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Md0zQN9AtzRsos3i]{Knighthood} page and need not read any further unless curious.

Next: @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.hkdvxbEDAI7rM6wc]{Start & Scope}
The players can only make interesting choices when they are presented with difficult situations and given all of the information needed to engage with them.

All Knights seek Glory, that they might one day be deemed worthy of the City Quest.

GLORY THROUGH MYTHS

When the group feels that a Myth has been resolved, reaching a conclusion of any type, all Knights who played a part in that Myth gain 1 Glory.

GLORY BY OTHER MEANS

In a public duel or joust, Knights may stake Glory against a willing opponent. The victor gains 1 Glory, the loser loses 1 Glory.

Tournaments may also grant 1 Glory to the winning Knight, provided there are significant spectators and spectacle.

If a battle is large enough to be remembered in history, all Knights on the victorious side gain 1 Glory.

When the game moves to a new Age all Knights gain 1 Glory through serving the Realm and manoeuvring in Court.

RANK

A Knight’s Glory dictates their rank:

0 Glory - Knight-Errant
Worthy of leading a Warband

3 Glory - Knight-Gallant
Worthy of a seat in Council or Court

6 Glory - Knight-Tenant
Worthy of ruling a Holding

9 Glory - Knight-Dominant
Worthy of ruling a Seat of Power

12 Glory - Knight-Radiant
Worthy of the City Quest

Work on existing buildings or infrastructure is generally completed by the next @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season}.

New buildings or infrastructure can be completed in a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.BuleIJa3bFxPopzQ]{Season}.

Grand projects such as castles and roads require an entire @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.9btBt0rE5AvXw3mt]{Age} of work.

Guard (GD) is your skill at avoiding Wounds.

When a target is damaged, the damage is first deducted from their GD.
Nature fights every step. Devise a solution, push through (lose [[/r d6]] in a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.a3wuqgFMQEMjrm0S]{Virtue}, usually VIG), or go back the way you came.
Hefty weapons require one hand. Only one Hefty item can be wielded at once.

Holdings are typically castles, walled towns, fortresses, or towers, held by Knights or influential Vassals. Most of the @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.3hsMdqsglAWNjUQu]{Realm} lives within their walls or the surrounding Hex.

One holding in each realm is @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ml5gCjU1JAnzXajw]{The Seat of Power}. This is the Holding of the ruler of the whole Realm, commonly a Knight.
When sleeping indoors, do not make a Wilderness Roll. Manners dictate that hospitality be granted to travelling Knights. Longer stays warrant a favour in return.
Impaired attacks roll d4 only and cannot gain bonus dice or benefit from Feats.

When faced with a question not answered by rules, notes, or procedures, you improvise.

Anything too beneficial or too harmful creates the feeling of an arbitrary world. Instead, describe something that does at least one of the following:

  • Evokes the flavour and themes of the area and its inhabitants.

  • Indulges their senses. Vision, hearing, touch, smell, and taste.

  • Reinforces something that they've already learned about this place.

You are Knights, united by a common Oath and visions of the City. You may have dreams of glory, but every Knight must accept the risk of death.

The Seers who knighted you have deemed that you travel as a Company. While some of you may rest, roam, or die, your collective journey will be as one.

Knights have 3 @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.a3wuqgFMQEMjrm0S]{Virtues}. Roll a value for each in order. The Start that you chose for your Company determines the dice you roll. If unsure, roll [[/r d12+d6]].

VIGOUR
Strong limbs, firm hands, powerful lungs.

CLARITY
Keen instinct, lucid mind, shrewd eyes.

SPIRIT
Charming tongue, iron will, fierce heart.

Roll for @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.oY1Asu19v9iHa8zw]{Guard (GD)}, your skill at avoiding Wounds. The Start that you chose for your Company determines the dice you roll. If unsure, roll [[/r d6]].

Roll ([[/r 1d6+1d12]]) or choose a Knight.

This gives:

Property: Items brought with you.

Ability: A special talent unique to you.

Passion: A special means you have to restore your Spirit.

Every Knight has a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.items.QCO3X6n1tHqez2DV]{Dagger} ([[/r d6]]), torches, rope, dry rations, and camping gear.

Every Knight knows the three @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Ii4ZqGwzc3qZWA8B]{Feats}.

Every Knight has sworn the Oath:

SEEK THE MYTHS

HONOUR THE SEERS

PROTECT THE REALM

• Those who take the Oath are held in esteem, but expectations burden them.

  • They rely on their arms, but are expected to know the customs of peace.

  • Usually one Knight holds each title, passed on in retirement or death

Each Knight can be used for a player character or non-player Knights who are encountered wandering or ruling. Generally each player should have a different type of Knight.

Some Realms refer to Knights by honorific titles and ranks, others their given name and home, while most use their full knightly title or simply “Knight.”

Some Wilderness Hexes contain a Landmark. These are discovered when travellers roll 4-6 on the Wilderness roll. A typical Realm has 3 or 4 of each type of Landmark.

Even characters who know a Landmark’s location must still make a Wilderness Roll to check for Omens as they travel there.

Each Landmark type covers a range of specific features, with prompts provided on Knight and Myth pages in the book.

The course of the game may create new Landmarks or remove or alter existing ones.

The 6 types of landmarks are:

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.gEhHqMT5ciuQNZXm]{Dwellings}

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.QWZ5Xsa3vuo5Bf69]{Sanctums}

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.lBdvsLmaxCzXExnv]{Monuments}

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.UuZ3UFDChYMN7gTh]{Hazards}

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ihrxnfnNnK4x8KPd]{Curses}

  • @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.TuBkbx1jAFCmrp19]{Ruins}

Each Hex is large and diverse, a land within the land. Some may spend their whole lives within one. A forest Hex might have cliffs, streams, clearings, and caves.

Use Spark Tables and the prompts at the base of each Knight and Myth spread to help fill the blanks in your Hexes.

When arriving in a Holding, roll to gauge the local mood.

[[/r 1d6]]

LOCAL MOOD

1

Occupied by a looming or recent woe.

2-3

There is a sense of things in decline.

4-6

A fine mood and all seems well enough.
Long weapons require both hands and are @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.w0AdMBWGQLWhQHd8]{Impaired} in confined environments.

If you need to consult the whims of fate, make a Luck Roll on a d6. A high roll favours the players, a low one does not.

In general, use these guidelines:

[[/r 1d6]]

LUCK ROLL

1

Crisis: Something immediately bad.

2-3

Problem: Something potentially bad.

4-6

Blessing: A welcome result.
Changing weapons, dismounting, and similar actions do not count as a combatant’s action for the turn.

If a season ends with 3 or more unresolved @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.VKF3X9roMxCO2nPp]{Crises} then the @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.Ht6YdS1x8Va8s16q]{Domain} goes into misrule. Vassals revolt, Knights leave, and pretenders move in on their claims.
Sites of inspiration. Travellers may spend a Phase to restore SPI here as if they were consuming a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.items.B2owmLXQ62SX30oD]{Sacrament}.

If a character is struck and loses half or more of their remaining VIG it is a mortal wound

Mortally Wounded targets are down and dying. They die if left untended for an hour, but can be patched up in a few moments.

Mounted combatants use their steed’s trample Damage in addition to their own weapons when charging enemies on foot. This doesn’t work against spearwalls. Steeds can be targeted separately by attacks.

Being dismounted causes [[/r 1d6]] Damage. If this occurs in combat, add it to the existing dice.

A typical @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.ml5gCjU1JAnzXajw]{Seat of Power} can muster 3 @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.IemxfFfJIeEBZp2e]{Warbands}, other Holdings 2. The @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.cQMFWOJXOBNZTa5w]{The Marshal} determines their training and armament.

Ending a phase in the Hex containing a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.zR5oyR4ZccCyWZg2]{Myth} always reveals its next @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.T3loxnAcV5W8mGZz]{Omen} without making a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.PxSDkx5wU6kRX5V3]{Wilderness Roll}. When possible, the Knights also get the drop on the Omen.

• Stories that became truths, or are destined to come to pass.

  • Nobody agrees on the details, but every version is true in some way.

  • There’s no such thing as “just a myth”.

Each Myth lists its Omens and the cast of beings who are associated with it.

A Knight’s journey largely focuses on travelling great distances to seek the guidance of Seers and uncover Myths.

However, on occasion there may be the need to zoom in on a single Hex, or a specific site within a Hex, in more detail.

Sites can be created as areas that warrant more detailed exploration, whether ancient tombs, hostile castles, twisting caverns, or misty woods spanning the entire Hex.

While they can be plotted out with any number of traditional methods, this is a quick Hex-based method.

POINTS AND ROUTES

  1. Draw 6 points as the corners of a hexagon, with a 7th in the centre.

    1. Mark 3 points with circles. These are features that give information or set the mood.

    2. Mark 2 with triangles. These are dangers to be navigated carefully.

    3. Mark 1 with a diamond. This is treasure, a useful or valuable find.

    4. Erase the final point and assign numbers to the remaining points.

  2. Neighbouring points can be connected by three types of route.

    1. Draw 3 open routes with a solid line. These are straightforward paths between points.

    2. Draw 2 closed routes with a crossed line. Here something blocks the way, so creative thinking is required.

    3. Draw 1 hidden route with a dotted line. This path is only found through specific exploration of its connecting points or local knowledge.

  3. Make sure all points can be reached, even if one of the routes is closed or secret.

  4. If applicable, place an entrance in any point, and an optional hidden entrance.

BREAKING THE RULES

The guidelines on this page are just a starting point. Rearrange the distribution of the types of point, route, and entrance if it suits the theme of the site better.

So a sealed burial complex might have:

Points: 3 Treasures, 2 Dangers, 1 Feature
Routes: 3 Closed, 2 Secret, 1 Open
Entrances: 1 Entrance only

Marshal: Training and equipping soldiers, mustering them in times of war.

A @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.3hsMdqsglAWNjUQu]{Realm} is mapped on a hexagonal grid covering the loose rule of a Seat of Power. A 12x12 grid is typical, whether the Realm is landlocked, coastal, or an island chain.

Typically, players get a copy of the map with @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.dJeZTvmudZnjrS96]{Holdings} and general terrain marked. The distance covered by each hexagon is a Hecksleague, commonly called a Hex.

This distance represents a few loose factors:

  • The area a hill fort can overlook

  • The area that guards can patrol in a day

  • A return hike to a neighbouring Hex gets you home before dark

Only the rich deal in coins. Most trade is an exchange of raw materials, goods, or service. Frequent trades often grow into ongoing pledges of service, cooperation, or protection.

Individuals who are Wounded, or groups who lose half their number, must pass a SPI Save to avoid rout or surrender.

Organised groups roll once using their leader's SPI. Disorganised groups roll for each individual against their own SPI. This does not affect player characters.
One of each armour type (coat, plates, helm, shield) can be worn at once, combining their armour scores together. Plates and helm are generally not worn outside of battle.

If no type is noted, assume the weapon uses one hand and has no other restrictions.

Hefty weapons require one hand. Only one Hefty item can be wielded at once.

Long weapons require both hands and are @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.w0AdMBWGQLWhQHd8]{Impaired} in confined environments.

Slow weapons cannot be used if the attacker has moved this turn. They are also Long.

Most @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.dBonZyygROm4ueJN]{Hexes} are Wilderness, with a variety of terrain types. Spark Tables can help with this. As a general guide create clusters of d12 hexes of the same terrain type.

Some Hexes have a @UUID[Compendium.celestus.rules.CapdrFIR5fQTiMqQ]{Barrier} on one or more of their edges, typically a sudden altitude change or impassible feature. These cannot normally be travelled through. For a typical Realm, place a number of Barriers equal to one sixth of your total Hexes.

Most Realms have a navigable river passing through and a few large lakes spanning whole or multiple Hexes.

Rank alone does not immediately grant the Knight a Council position or rule of a Holding. It merely proves their worthiness.

A Knight may find themselves in a position for which their rank is unworthy. They are sure to face initial opposition, but if this can be overcome then their worthiness is proven.
